case_name: Co-operative Bank v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Orissa

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 228 to 230 of 1958 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 228 to 230 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgment and decree dated July 2, 1957 of Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Case No. 640 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and decree dated July 2, 1957, of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Case No. 640 of 1955.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Kapur, J. on February 22, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. February 22. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-

facts.text: Appellant is a bank registered under Co-operative Societies Act, 1912 and deemed registered under Bihar and Orissa Co-operative Societies Act, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a. Bank registered under the Co- operative Societies Act, 1912  Act II of 1912  and is deemed to be registered under the Bihar Orissa Co-operative Societies Act, 1935  Bihar Act VI of 1935  which in Bihar has replaced.

facts.text: Appellant bank carried on banking business in State of Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: It was carrying on banking business in the State of Bihar.

facts.text: One object of bank is to carry on general business of banking not repugnant to Bihar Act and rules (Bye-Law 3(vi)).

anchor.surface_text: One of the objects of the Bank is to carry on general business of banking number repugnant to the provisions of the Bihar Act and rules framed thereunder for the time being in force  Bye-Law 3 a vi .

facts.text: In calendar years 1945, 1946, 1947, appellant bank received interest on deposits with Imperial Bank of India: Rs. 7,192; Rs. 20,250; Rs. 22,600 respectively.

anchor.surface_text: In the calendar years 1945, 1946 and 1947, the appellant Bank received by way of interest on deposits with the Imperial Bank of India the sums of Rs. 7,192, Rs. 20,250 and Rs. 22,600 respectively.

facts.text: These sums subject of dispute in appeals for assessment years 1946-47, 1947-48, 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: It is these sums which are the subject matter of dispute in these three appeals which relate to the respective assessment years 1946-47, 1947-48 and 1948-49.

facts.text: Sums not assessed initially under s.23(3) Income-tax Act, but later assessed under s.34 as income under other sources.

anchor.surface_text: These sums were number assessed when assessment was made under s. 23 3  of the Income-tax Act, but subsequently under s. 34 they were assessed as being income under the head other sources.

facts.text: Assessment order upheld by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: This order was upheld by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Case stated to High Court under s.66(1), decided against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: A case was then stated to the High Court under s. 66 1  of the Act, but was decided against the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant showed sums as other sources in return.

anchor.surface_text: In its return the appellant showed these various sums as I other sources, but numberhing turns on the manner in which the appellant chose to show this income in its return.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer assessed interest under s.12 as income from other sources.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, however, assessed the interest for these three years under s. 12 of the Income-tax Act, as income from I other sources.

facts.text: Appellant contended before AAC that interest exempt under Notification s.60 due to business purpose of deposits.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant took an appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner where it was companytended that as the business of the appellant Bank companysisted of lending money and the deposits had been made number for the purpose of investment but for that business...

facts.text: AAC held deposits were investments of surplus funds, interest not exempt; noted investments Rs.13,50,000 in 1945, Rs.15,00,000 in 1946, realised 1947.

anchor.surface_text: He remarked that it appeared from the balance-sheets that in the accounting year 1945 the Bank invested Rs. 13,50,000 as fixed deposits, which, in the following year was raised to Rs. 15,00,000 and it was only in the accounting year 1947 that the fixed deposits were realised on maturity with interest.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal order dated April 11, 1955 held interest income under other sources, not exempt.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, by its order dated April 11, 1955, held- That the interest was an income rightly to be included under the head of I other sources.

facts.text: Two questions referred to High Court under s.66(1).

anchor.surface_text: Against this order a case was stated at the instance of the appellant under s. 66 1  of the Act, and the following two questions of law were referred...

facts.text: Notifications: C.B.R. No.35 dated October 20, 1934 and No.33 dated August 18, 1945 exempt profits of co-operative societies including from certain investments.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant portion of that Notification, C.B.R. Notification No. 35 dated October 20, 1934, and No. 33 dated August 18, 1945, was - The following classes of income shall be exempt...

facts.text: Appellant contended before Tribunal and HC that deposits for liquidity in business, short-term, part of banking business.

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court the appellants companytention was that the fixed deposits were made with the Imperial Bank of India number with the idea of making investments, but for the reason that cash should be available...

facts.text: High Court held interest from investments not part of co-operative business profits, not exempt.

anchor.surface_text: But the High Court did number accept this companytention. It held that if the income derived by a Co-operative Society was from the business of the Co-operative Society as such...

facts.text: Supreme Court held interest from fixed deposits is part of banking business profits under s.10, not other sources under s.12, exempt under notification.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court was in error in treating interest derived from deposits as number arising from the business of the Bank and therefore number falling within the income exempted under the Notification. The appeal must therefore be allowed...

facts.text: Deposits were fixed deposits renewed yearly but fell due at short intervals, available if needed.

anchor.surface_text: but as is shown by the accounts these deposits fell due at short intervals and would have been available to the appellant had any need arisen.

facts.text: Bye-laws provide bank could invest surplus funds per s.19 Bihar Act when not required for business.

anchor.surface_text: it was provided that the bank companyld I invest surplus funds when number required for the business of the bank in one or more ways specified in s. 19 of the Bihar Act  Cl. 4 111 i  of the Bye-Laws .
These sums were number assessed when assessment was made under s. 23 3  of the Income-tax Act, but subsequently under s. 34 they were assessed as being income under the head other sources.

anchor.surface_text: these various sums of interest were number subject to income- tax because of the Notification issued by the Central Government under s. 60 of the Income-tax Act. The relevant portion of that Notification, C.B.R. Notification No. 35 dated October 20, 1934

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: Co-operative Society other than the Sanikatta Salt Owners Society in the Bombay Presidency for the time being registered under the Co-operative Socie

anchor.surface_text: The relevant portion of that Notification, C.B.R. Notification No. 35 dated October 20, 1934, and No. 33 dated August 18, 1945, was - The following classes of income shall be exempt from the tax payable under the said Act... profits of any Co-operative Society... ExplanationFor this purpose the profits of a Co-operative Society shall number be deemed to include any income... from... s. 8... s. 9... s. 12

issues.text: Whether, in the facts and circumstances of this case, the receipt of interest on fixed deposits was an income under the head of other sources

anchor.surface_text: Against this order a case was stated at the instance of the appellant under s. 66 1  of the Act, and the following two questions of law were referred for the opinion of the High Court Whether, in the facts and circumstances of this case, the receipt of interest on fixed deposits was an income under the head of I other sources

issues.text: Whether in the facts and circumstances of this case, the receipt of interest from the fixed deposits was an income not exempt from taxation under the C. B. R. Notification No. 35 dated 20th October, 1934 and No. 33 dated the 18th August, 1945

anchor.surface_text: and Whether in the facts and circumstances of this case, the receipt of interest from the fixed deposits was an income number exempt from taxation under the C. B. R. Notification No. 35 dated 20th October, 1934 and No. 33 dated the 18th August, 1945.

issues.text: whether the investment by a Cooperative Bank of its assets in fixed deposits in the manner that the appellant Bank had deposited its moneys falls within the term business and is therefore assessable under s. 10 of the Income-tax Act, or it is an investment the interest from which would fall under the term other sources and therefore within s. 12 of the Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: the sole question for determination is whether the investment by a Cooperative Bank of its assets in fixed deposits... falls within the term I business and is there- fore assessable under s. 10 of the Income-tax Act, or it is an investment the interest from which would fall under the term I other sources and therefore within s. 12

arguments.claim: Deposits made not for investment but for business of lending money, fulfilling purpose of Co-operative Bank, so interest exempt under s.60 notification

anchor.surface_text: The appellant took an appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner where it was contended that as the business of the appellant Bank consisted of lending money and the deposits had been made not for the purpose of investment but for that business and thereby fulfilling the purpose for which the Co-operative Bank was constituted, these various sums of interest were not subject to income-tax because of the Notification issued by the Central Government under s. 60 of the Income-tax Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: investments, but in order that cash might be available to the appellant companytinuously for the carrying on of the purposes of its business, and that

arguments.court_reasoning: AAC held deposits were investments of surplus funds based on balance-sheets and period locked

arguments.claim: Fixed deposits with Imperial Bank were investments of surplus funds, not for business exigencies; interest not exempt

anchor.surface_text: He remarked that it appeared from the balance-sheets that in the accounting year 1945 the Bank invested Rs. 13,50,000 as fixed deposits, which, in the following year was raised to Rs. 15,00,000 and it was only in the accounting year 1947 that the fixed deposits were realised on maturity with interest. He was also of the opinion that the length of the period during which this money was kept locked in this way showed clearly that not the exigencies of pressing necessities, but the motives of investment of surplus fund had actuated the deposits.

arguments.court_reasoning: Deposits fell due at short intervals and available if needed; normal banking practice

arguments.claim: Deposits not as investments but for continuous cash availability for business; intimately connected, interest is business profit

anchor.surface_text: Against this order an appeal was taken to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal and it was there contended that the Bank did not make the deposits as investments, but in order that cash might be available to the appellant continuously for the carrying on of the purposes of its business, and that the deposits were intimately connected with the business of the appellant and therefore the interest should have been held to be profits arising from the business activities of the Bank,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: They have both treated it as a question of law and it is on that basis that the reference was made. The decision of the question depends on what is c

arguments.court_reasoning: Tribunal held interest under other sources from surplus investments

arguments.claim: Interest income rightly under other sources; profits of co-op society mean from its business, not from surplus investments like fixed deposits

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, by its order dated April 11, 1955, held- That the interest was an income rightly to be included under the head of other sources. The profits of a Co-operative Society indicates the profit derived from the business which can be truly called the business of the Co-operative Society. Investments by the society either in securities or in shares or in bank fixed deposits are made out of surplus funds.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: . 396.  3  1940 8 I.T.R. 635 that in the instant case the moneys had been deposited with the Imperial Bank on long term deposits inasmuch as they were

arguments.court_reasoning: For banking business, such deposits part of dealing in money

arguments.claim: Fixed deposits not investments but for cash availability as needed; short-term, essential for business; interest part of business profits

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court the appellants contention was that the fixed deposits were made with the Imperial Bank of India not with the idea of making investments, but for the reason that cash should be available to the appellant as and when it was needed for the purposes of its business. It was also contended that the deposits were short-term deposits and that the Bank could not carry on its business without such short-term deposits.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: interest. It was held that interest from securities was number part of the profits of the business of the society as it was number obliged to invest i

arguments.court_reasoning: HC held investment of surplus not part of co-op business

arguments.claim: Income from co-op business as such exempt, but from investment of surplus assets with third parties not; not part of co-op banking business

anchor.surface_text: But the High Court did not accept this contention. It held that if the income derived by a Co-operative Society was from the business of the Co-operative Society as such, it fell within the exemption, but if it arose out of the business with third parties as in the case of investment of surplus assets, the exemption was inapplicable because the investment of fluid assets was not a part of the business of the Co-operative Bank

court_response_anchor.surface_text: . 396.  3  1940 8 I.T.R. 635 that in the instant case the moneys had been deposited with the Imperial Bank on long term deposits inasmuch as they were

arguments.court_reasoning: SC disagreed, held part of banking business

arguments.claim: Tribunal finding on nature of deposits is finding of fact

anchor.surface_text: It was contended by the learned Solicitor-General that the finding of the Appellate Tribunal as to the nature of these deposits was one of fact. This contention is not sustainable. It has not been treated as a finding of fact either by the Appellate Tribunal or by the High Court.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: terest derived therefrom was number profits of the business. Counsel for the respondent relied on a judgment of the Punjab High Court in Hoshiarpur Ce

arguments.court_reasoning: Not treated as fact finding by lower courts; treated as law

arguments.claim: Business of bank dealing in money/credit; deposits with other banks part of business like lending; serves to earn interest and liquidity

anchor.surface_text: Relying upon the decision of the Privy Council in The Punjab Co-operative Bank Ltd v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab, counsel for the appellant submitted that the business of a bank is one of dealing in money and credit and that laying out moneys in deposit with other banks is just as much a mode of conducting business as lending moneys to borrowers whether members of the society or to other co operative societies, and is therefore a part of the appellants business.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: . 396.  3  1940 8 I.T.R. 635 that in the instant case the moneys had been deposited with the Imperial Bank on long term deposits inasmuch as they were

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed, normal banking to keep liquid earning interest

arguments.claim: Laying out moneys in deposits not carrying on bank business; interest from such is other sources

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the respondent argued that where moneys are so laid out they cannot be termed carrying on business of the bank and therefore any sums coming in from such investments cannot be termed profits arising from business, but they are income from other sources.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: . 396.  3  1940 8 I.T.R. 635 that in the instant case the moneys had been deposited with the Imperial Bank on long term deposits inasmuch as they were

arguments.court_reasoning: None support; those were securities not short-term deposits; some sent back for reconsideration

arguments.claim: Interest on fixed deposits part of banking business under s.10, not other sources s.12; deposits short-term available; normal to employ circulating capital this way

anchor.surface_text: but as is shown by the accounts these deposits fell due at short intervals and would have been available to the appellant had any need arisen. ... That is how the circulating capital is employed and that is the normal course of business of a bank. The moneys laid out in the form of deposits as in the instant case would not cease to be a part of the circulating capital of the appellant nor would they cease to form part of its banking business.

arguments.claim: Heads under s.6 mutually exclusive; s.12 residuary only after excluding prior heads like business s.10

anchor.surface_text: It may be added that the various heads under s. 6 of the Income Tax Act and the provisions of that Act applicable to these various heads are mutually exclusive. Section 12 is a residuary section and does not come into operation until the preceding heads are excluded.

arguments.claim: High Court erred; interest arises from bank business, falls within exempted notification profits

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court was in error in treating interest derived from deposits as not arising from the business of the Bank and therefore not falling within the income exempted under the Notification. The appeal must therefore be allowed and the judgment and order of the High Court set aside.

arguments.claim: Bye-laws allow investment of surplus under s.19 Bihar Act, but these not shown to be surplus outside business

anchor.surface_text: it was provided that the bank could invest surplus funds when not required for the business of the bank in one or more ways specified in s. 19 of the Bihar Act Cl. 4 iii i of the Bye-Laws . Whether funds invested as provided in s. 19 of the Bihar Act would be surplus or not does not arise for decision in this case,

arguments.court_reasoning: Issue not arising; not shown to be surplus per bye-law

arguments.claim: Cases like Punjab Co-op support deposits as part of banking

anchor.surface_text: The Privy Council in The Punjab Cooperative Bank Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Incometax, Lahore where the profits arose from the sale of Government securities pointed out at p. 645 that in the ordinary cases the business of a Bank essentially consists of dealing with money and credit.

arguments.claim: Cited cases like Hoshiarpur not applicable as those activities outside objects

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the respondent relied on a judgment of the Punjab High Court in Hoshiarpur Central Cooperative Bank v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Simla . In that case the Government authorised the Bank to deal in sugar, oil and standard cloth and it made profit therefrom. Those activities were neither its business under the bye-laws nor within its objects.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not applicable to facts; deposits within objects

holdings.text: Interest derived from fixed deposits arises from the business of the Bank and therefore falls within the income exempted under the Notification

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court was in error in treating interest derived from deposits as number arising from the business of the Bank and therefore number falling within the income exempted under the Notification. The appeal must therefore be allowed and the judgment and order of the High Court set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Banking business involves dealing in money and credit; short-term deposits maintain liquidity while earning interest as normal banking practice; part of circulating capital; heads of income mutually exclusive with s.12 residuary

holdings.text: The moneys laid out in the form of deposits would not cease to be a part of the circulating capital of the appellant nor would they cease to form part of its banking business; returns flowing from them form part of its profits from business

anchor.surface_text: but as is shown by the accounts these deposits fell due at short intervals and would have been available to the appellant had any need arisen. ... That is how the circulating capital is employed and that is the normal course of business of a bank. The moneys laid out in the form of deposits as in the instant case would not cease to be a part of the circulating capital of the appellant nor would they cease to form part of its banking business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deposits fell due at short intervals and available if needed; normal mode of conducting banking business to employ circulating capital this way instead of idle; aligns with objects and bye-laws

holdings.text: The various heads under s.6 of the Income Tax Act and provisions applicable to them are mutually exclusive; s.12 is residuary and does not come into operation until preceding heads are excluded

anchor.surface_text: It may be added that the various heads under s. 6 of the Income Tax Act and the provisions of that Act applicable to these various heads are mutually exclusive. Section 12 is a residuary section and does not come into operation until the preceding heads are excluded.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation of income heads; s.12 applies only after excluding business profits under s.10

holdings.text: Finding of the Appellate Tribunal as to the nature of these deposits was not one of fact; contention that it was finding of fact not sustainable

anchor.surface_text: terest derived therefrom was number profits of the business. Counsel for the respondent relied on a judgment of the Punjab High Court in Hoshiarpur Ce

holdings.reasoning_summary: Neither Tribunal nor High Court treated it as finding of fact; reference made on basis it was question of law

holdings.text: Whether funds invested as provided in s.19 of the Bihar Act would be surplus or not does not arise for decision in this case

holdings.text: Cited cases like Madras Central Urban Bank, Madras Provincial Co-operative Bank etc. do not support that interest from deposits is other sources

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the respondent relied on a judgment of the Punjab High Court in Hoshiarpur Central Cooperative Bank v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Simla . In that case the Government authorised the Bank to deal in sugar, oil and standard cloth and it made profit therefrom. Those activities were neither its business under the bye-laws nor within its objects.

precedents.case_name: Cochin Cottage Industries Cooperative Marketing Society Ltd v Commissioner of Income Tax Mysore
precedents.cited_proposition: apportioned profit from dealings with non-members not exempt

precedents.citation: Surat Peoples Co-operative Bank Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Ahmedabad 2 1958 33 I.T.R. 396

anchor.surface_text: In the Surat Peoples Co-operative Bank Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Ahmedabad 2 1958 33 I.T.R. 396. the profit arose during the companyrse of banking business out of the sale of Government securities which formed part of the stock-in-trade and as it was a company operative bank the profits made from such sales were held to be exempt from taxation under the Notification.

precedents.case_name: Surat Peoples Co-operative Bank Ltd v Commissioner of Income-tax Ahmedabad
precedents.cited_proposition: profit from sale of Government securities part of stock-in-trade is exempt for co-operative bank

precedents.citation: The Punjab Cooperative Bank Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Incometax, Lahore 3 1940 8 I.T.R. 635

anchor.surface_text: The Privy Council in The Punjab Cooperative Bank Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Incometax, Lahore 3 1940 8 I.T.R. 635 where the profites arose from the sale of Government securities pointed out at p. 645 that in the ordinary cases the business of a Bank essentially companysists of dealing with money and credit.

precedents.case_name: Punjab Cooperative Bank Ltd v Commissioner of Income-tax Lahore
precedents.cited_proposition: business of a Bank consists of dealing with money and credit; keeping cash or easily realizable securities to meet demands is normal step in banking business
